name: sounds made by objects, movement or impact

children.name: clap
children.definition: to make a short loud noise by hitting your hands together
examples: "When I clap my hands, you must stand still," said the teacher.
The band played a familiar tune which had everyone clappingalong.
The audience clappedin time tothe music.

children.name: click
children.definition: to make a short, sharp sound, or to make sth do this
examples: The door clicked shut behind her.
click your fingers(= make a short sound with your fingers to get someone's attention )
She clicks her fingers and he comes running.
click your tongue(= make a short sound with your tongue to show disapproval )
She clicked her tongue in annoyance.
click your heels(= hit the heels of your shoes together, as a soldier does )
He clicked his heels and saluted.
click into place/ positionMake sure the lid clicks firmly into place.
click open/shut(= open with a short hard sound )
I heard the gate at the front of the house click open.

children.name: murmur
children.definition: the continuous, low, quiet sound of sth that is a fairly long way away or that is continuously there as well as other noises:tiếng lầm rầm, bùm bụp
examples: Jan had the radio on in the room above, but it was no more than a murmur.
the murmur of sth
The murmur of distant traffic reached us when the wind was in the east.

children.name: rustle
children.definition: if things such as papers, leaves, or clothesrustle, they make a continuous quiet sound as they rub against each other:xào xạt, sột soạt
examples: Leaves rustled in the summer breeze.
The tissue paper rustled in the silence as she unwrapped the gift.
rustle[CS noun]
There was no sound in the library except for the occasional rustle of papers.

children.name: swish
children.definition: the smooth quiet sound produced when sth such as a skirt or curtains moves quickly through the air:
examples: The magnificent red stage curtains opened with a swish.
the swish of sth
Just then there was the swish of wings right above my head.
swish[T verb]
Horses try to keep flies off by swishing their tails from side to side.

children.name: creak
children.definition: if something creaks, especially somethingwoodensuch as a door, bed, or stair, it makes a long, high noise when sb puts pressure on it:cót két
examples: In the hall the floorboards creaked and the walls were damp.
creak open
The key clicked inside the lock and the door creaked open.
creak/ creaking[CS noun]
Then I heard the creak of someone’s footsteps on the stairs.
the creaking of the boats in the harbou

children.name: screech
children.definition: to make a loud, long, unpleasant high sound, like the sound made by car tyres when the car stops suddenly:
examples: The train screeched as it pulled into the station.
screech[CS noun]
There was the screech of brakes and then a tremendous bang

children.name: squeak
children.definition: if sth squeaks, it makes a veryhighnoiseas it is moved, pushed etc, especially because two parts of it cannotrubsmoothly together:
examples: His chair squeaked loudly as he swivelled round to face me.
The rubber soles of my shoes squeaked on the shiny floor.
squeak[CS noun]
The only sound was the soft squeak of the marker on the board.
squeaky[adj]
an old desk with squeaky drawers

children.name: sounds by sth hitting or falling onto sth
bang
children.definition: a loud sound caused especially when sth hard or heavy hits sth else or falls on a surface:
examples: I heard a loud bang - it sounded like something had fallen down upstairs.
make a bang
Small children are often frightrened of fireworks that make a bang.
close/ land/ collide etc with a bang
The lid of the box fell shut with a bang.

children.name: thud
children.definition: the low dull sound produced when sth heavy but soft hits sth else or falls on a surface:tiếng bịch
examples: I heard a shot, followed by a thud as his body hit the floor.
hit/ drop/ land etc with a thud
A snowball hit her on the back of the neck with a soft thud.
the thud of
Suddenly we heard the thud of horses’ hooves.

children.name: crack
children.definition: a loud sudden very sharp sound like the sound of a stick being broken:tiếng nứt, gãy rắc rắc
examples: The branch broke with a sudden crack
As I hit the floor, I heard a loud crack in my arm.

children.name: crash
children.definition: the very loud sound produced when sth hard such as metal or glass hits sth else or falls on a surface, especially when damage is caused:tiếng vỡ, rắc
examples: There was a loud crash in the bedroom and my dad startedyelling.
fall/ land/ hit etc sth with a crash
The whole tray of dishes fell to the floor with a crash.

children.name: bump
children.definition: the dull, fairly quiet sound produced when sth such as part of your body hits sth or falls against a surface:tiếng bụp
examples: At night, the old house seemed to be full of strange creaks and bumps .
fall/ sit down/ hit etc sth with a bump
Martin sat down suddenly with a bump.

children.name: clatter
children.definition: the loud sound produced when a lot of hard things hit against each other or hit a hard surface:tiếng loảng xoảng
examples: The clatter in the kitchen told me that Mum was already up.
fall/ drop etc sth with a clatter
Bert put down his tools with a clatter, and looked round the room.
the clatter of sth
Just then there was the clatter of hooves on the road outside.

children.name: thump
children.definition: the dull, fairly loud sound produced when sth heavy suddenly hits sth else or falls hard on a surface:tiếng bụp mạnh
examples: There was a loud thump as Eddie threw Luther back against the wall.
hit sth/ fall etc with a thump
A suitcase toppled off the top of the wardrobe and landed on the floor with a thump.

children.name: sounds by sth burning or cooking
crackle
children.definition: if a fire or sth burning in a firecrackles,it makes a repeated sharp sound:tách tách, răng rắc
examples: A log crackled on the fire.
In the living-room, a huge fire was crackling away.
crackle[CS noun]
the crackle of the bonfire

children.name: sizzle
children.definition: to produce the continuous sound that is made, for example by food being cooked in very hot oil:kêu xèo xèo
examples: Bacon was sizzling in the frying pan.
It was so hot that the water just sizzled and evaporated.
sizzle[CS noun]tiếng kêu xèo xèo
The sizzle and smell of hamburgers and sausages greeted us as we walked out the back door.

children.name: sounds by sth repeatedly hitting sth
knocking
children.definition: the sound produced when sth hard keeps hitting another hard surface:tiếng gõ, lóc cóc
examples: One of the machines started to make a strange knocking sound.
The builders’ knocking and hammering made it difficult for me to concentrate on my work.

children.name: rap
children.definition: / rapping the sound produced when sb keeps hitting a surface, especially a door or window, with their hand or with a hard object:tiếng đập cửa, bàn, etc
examples: rap/ rapping at/on etc
A violent rap at the door made me run downstairs
I was kept awake by the rapping of a branch on my window.

children.name: patter
children.definition: to make a quiet irregular sound, like the sound of rain falling or quick, light steps:tí tách, lộp cộp
examples: patter on/in etc
Raindrops were pattering on the car roof.
patter about/aroundmove around with a pattering sound
I could hear feet shuffling and pattering about upstairs.
patter/ pattering[CS noun]tiếng tí tách/ lộp cộp
the patter of sth
the patter of mice in the attic

children.name: tap
children.definition: to produce a sound by lightly and repeatedly hitting a hard surface:
examples: gõ nhẹ, vỗ nhẹ, đập nhẹ
tap on/against:đập nhẹ, gõ nhẹ trên
Is that someone tapping on the door?
It sounded as though something outside was tapping against the window.
tapping[CS noun]tiếng đập nhẹ, gõ nhẹ
What are they doing next door? I can’t stand this constant tapping on the wall.

children.name: rattle
children.definition: if sth rattles, it makes a hard, quickly repeated sound, especially because part of it is loose and keeps hitting against sth:lọc cọc, lách cách
examples: There’s something rattling inside the washing machine.
The windows were rattling in the wind.
I woke up to the sound of cups and plates rattling, and knew that Dad was already up.
rattle about/aroundmove around with a rattling sound
Sometimes, the bolts work loose and start rattling around.
rattle along/past etcmove somewhere making a rattling sound
A battered old Chevrolet rattled past.
rattle/ rattling[CS noun]
I heard the rattle of a key in the door, and knew David was home.
Just then we heard the rattle of a key in the lock.

children.name: sounds by glass or metal hitting sth
clink
children.definition: if sth made of glass or metal clinks, it makes a short ringing sound as it hits another glass or metal object: kêuleng keng
examples: Their champagne glasses clinked. ‘Happy Anniversary Darling,’ Roger said.
clink against
She wore at least twenty bracelets, which clinked against each other every time she moved her arm.
clink/ clinking[CS noun]
The clink of dishes in the dining room told him that dinner would soon be ready.
clinking[adj]
sounds of clinking cutlery and glass

children.name: clank
children.definition: if sth heavy made of metalclanks, it makes a short, loud noise as it hits another metal object:lẻng kẻng
examples: The train’s carriages clanked and rattled as it crept into the station.
In the harbor, the boats’ rigging clanked noisily in the high wind.
clank/ clanking[CS noun]
Then I heard the clanking of the metal gates outside, followed by footsteps on the path.

children.name: clang
children.definition: if sth metal clangs, it makes a loud, long ringing noise when it hits another metal object:keng
examples: Somewhere inside the courtyard a bell clanged.
clang shut
The prison door clanged shut again.
clang[Cs noun]
I dropped the metal bar and it hit the floor with a loud clang.
clanging[adj]
The sound echoed in Matt’s head like a clanging cymbal.

children.name: jingle
children.definition: if a set of thingsjingle, especially things made of metal or glass, they make a continuous high musical sound as they hit each other:leng ken, xổn xoảng
examples: The coins in his pocket jingled together noisily.
A herd of goats crossed the beach, the bells around their necks jingling cheerfully.
jingle[CS noun]
Just then there was the jingle of keys outside the door.

children.name: ring U
children.definition: ring if sthrings, it makes a high, loud, continuous sound after it hits another object:
examples: If you tap sth made of good glass, it should keep ringing for quite a long time.
ringing[adj]
There was a ringing sound in my ears.

children.name: tinkle
children.definition: to produce the pleasant, high, continuous sound that is made, for example, by light pieces of glass or metal hitting each other: leng keng
examples: I rang the bell and heard it tinkle inside.
The ring fell from her hands and went tinkling across the floor.
tinkle/ tinkling[CS noun]
the tinkle of glass and china

children.name: bang
children.definition: a short sudden loud noise made by a gun, bomb etc:tiếng nổ
examples: ‘I heard a bang and then I heard shots,’ said Saxton, a tourist from Australia.
loud bang
There was a loud bang as the bomb exploded.
go off/ explode etc with a bang
The firework went off with a loud bang.

children.name: boom
children.definition: an extremely loud noise that can be heard for several seconds after it begins:tiếng ầm ầm, đùng đùng
examples: The boom of cannon continued for most of the day
There was a loud boom. The chemical works was on fire.
sonic boomthe loud noise made when a plane, spacecraft etc passes the speed of soundtiếng nổ siêu thanh
A sonic boom was heard by observers on the shore as the meteorite fell to earth.

children.name: roar
children.definition: anextremelyloud noise that gets gradually louder and continues for a fairly long time:tiếng gầm gừ
examples: With a great roar, the whole building was engulfed in flames.
We threw ourselves to the ground as the roar of an explosion thundered over us.

children.name: rumble
children.definition: to make a very low sound, like the sound of distant thunder, that gets quieter then louder continuously:nổ ầm ầm, đùng đùng
examples: In the distance, thunder rumbled across the sky.
The sound of rebel gunfire rumbled in the hills.
rumble[CS noun]tiếng nổ ầm ầm, đùng đùng
What began as a rumble became a powerful roar as the volcano erupted.

children.name: sounds by bells or horns, warning devices
ring
children.definition: to make a sound like that of a bell: reo
examples: The phone’s ringing.
A burglar alarm was ringing further along the road.
At that moment, the door bell rang.

children.name: toll
children.definition: if alargebelltolls,it makes regular, separate ringing sounds, especially as a sign of sb’sdeath:reo
examples: The funeral procession left the church as the bells began to toll.

children.name: chime
children.definition: if a bell or clockchimes, it makes a single ringing sound or a small number of ringing sounds, especially in order to tell you what time it is:đánh chuông, đổ chuông
examples: I heard a clock chime softly in the next door room.
Across the valley, church bells were chiming.
chime six/ eight/ twelve etc
A clock chimed six.
chime[C noun]
The shop door opened with a chime.

children.name: go off
children.definition: if sth goes off, it starts making a noise - use this aboutwarning bells, clocksthat tell you it is time to get up etc:đổ chuông
examples: My neighbour’s car alarm went off three times last night.
I get up as soon as the alarm clock goes off at 7:15.

children.name: honk
children.definition: informal if youhonka vehicle’s horn or if the hornhonks, it makes a loud clear sound which continues for only a few seconds:còi
examples: Several horns honked impatiently.
The truck driver honked his horn and waited.

children.name: hoot
children.definition: if youhoota vehicle’s horn, or if the hornhoots, it makes a loud clear sound which continues for only a few seconds and is like a single musical note:bóp còi
examples: A horn hooted behind me. It was Don in his little red car.
All the other drivers were tooting their horns and yelling at me to move my car.
hoot/ hooting[C noun]tiếng bóp kèn
She gave three short hoots on the car horn.
He gave a hootoflaughter/derision.

children.name: sounds by machines, engines, cars etc
buzz
children.definition: to make a continuous sound, for example, like the sound made by bees:kêu vo vo
examples: Police helicopters buzzed backwards and forwards over the area all day.
The whole office seemed to be buzzing with the sound of machinery.
buzz[CS noun] [C2]tiếng kêu vo vo
I could hear the buzz of a chainsaw far away among the trees.

children.name: hum
children.definition: to make a soft, low continuous sound like the sound made by some electric or electronic equipment:
examples: The refrigerator hummed softly in the corner.
The computer was still on, humming away.
hum[CS noun] tiếng kêu rền
the hum of the air conditioning

children.name: whirr
children.definition: to make a fairly quiet, regular sound like sth turning very quickly and beating against the air:vù vù, vèo vèo
examples: The video recorder whirred and rewound.
Already the plane’s propellers were whirring into action.
whirr[CS noun]tiếng kêu vù vù, vèo vèo
At last the engine started up with a grinding whirr.

children.name: whine
children.definition: an unpleasant long high sound, especially produced by an engine or vehicle running at very high speed:tiếng rít xe, máy
examples: The sky was filled with the whine and roar of bombers.

children.name: beep
children.definition: /bleep  a high, sometimes repeated, electronic sound sent out by a machine, especially in order to attract sb’s attention:tiếng kêu bíp
examples: You’ll hear a bleep when the photocopier’s finished printing.
Someone’s pager beeped in the middle of the best scene in the play.
beep/ bleep[I verb]kêu bíp bíp
The machine bleeps if you leave it switched on for more than 10 minutes.

children.name: roar
children.definition: if a car, plane etc engine roars, it makes a very loud noise when it is near full power:gầm gừ
examples: The Ferrari roared and shot off down the road.
roar past/ along etcmove with a roaring sound
There was the sound of a siren and several police cars roared past.
roar[CS noun] [C2]tiếng gầm gầm
The boat’s motor made quite a roar.
His apartment was on a main road and there wasaconstant roarof traffic.

children.name: tick
children.definition: if a clock or other machineticks, it makes a quiet, regular, repeated sound:kêu tíc tắc
examples: I find it impossible to sleep if there’s a clock ticking in the room.
As usual, there was a bomb ticking somewhere and James Bond had to find it.
tick/ ticking[CS noun]tiếng kêu tíc tắc
Jeremy waited anxiously, listening to the ticking of the clock on the wall.

children.name: hiss
children.definition: if sth such as a tyre, ball, or part of a machine hisses, it makes a continuous high sound as air, water etc escapes from it:xì xì, xèo xèo
examples: Air hissed out of the tyre.
It sounded as though gas was hissing out of a pipe.
hiss[CS noun]tiếng xì xì, xèo xèo
The train halted with a loud hiss of escaping steam.

children.name: fizz
children.definition: to produce the continuous high sound that is made for example by some kinds of drinks that produce bubbles when they are poured into a glass:xì, nổ lốp bốp
examples: I dropped the tablet in the glass. It fizzed and dissolved.
The firework fizzed for a moment and then went off with a bang.

children.name: sounds by liquids or sth wet
splash
children.definition: the sound that a liquid makes when it falls from a height, hits sth hard, or is moved rapidly around:tiếng bắn nước tung tóe
examples: There was a splash behind the boat as a large silver fish jumped out of the water.
Judging from the shouts and splashes coming from the pool, everyone was having a lot of fun.
fall/ land etc with a splash
Ashlee fell into the river with a loud splash.
splash[I verb]tóe nước
The waterfall cascaded over the rocks and splashed into a pool at the bottom.

children.name: squelch
children.definition: to make a sound like sb walking in soft, wet mud, or to move somewhere making this sound:kêu lép nhép, ì ọp
examples: It had been raining hard and my boots squelched as I walked across the park.
squelch along/ past/ through etc
Ankle deep in mud, we squelched across the meadow.
squelch around
Melvin was squelching around in the yard outside the cowshed.
squelch[C usually sing] a sucking sound like the one produced when you are walking on soft wet ground
As the hikers walked down the path by the house, she could hear the squelch of their boots in the mud.

children.name: gurgle
children.definition: if sth such as a streamgurgles, it makes a low irregular sound like water flowing through a pipe:kêu ùng ục, ồng ọc
examples: The pipes in the attic gurgle in the night and keep me awake.
The washing machine gurgled as it changed cycles.
gurgle[CS noun]tiếng kêu ùng ùng, ồng ộc
Somewhere nearby there was the gentle gurgle of a stream.

children.name: plop
children.definition: to make a sound like sth solid falling directly into water:rơi tõm
examples: plop into/onto etc
Noah threw a stone high into the air and it plopped into the river.
Several letters plopped onto the doormat.
plop/ plopping[CS noun]tiếng rơi tõm
The frog reached the stream and jumped in with a plop.

children.name: bubble
children.definition: to make the continuous repeated sound that is made, for example, by water boiling:sùng sục
examples: A large saucepan of soup was bubbling on the stove.
bubbling[adj]kêu sùng sục
Josh lay back in the bubbling jacuzzi.
